Section.Description: This section summarizes the environmental fate/exposure of this chemical, including the natural and artificial sources of the chemical as a pollutant, its environmental fate, biodegradation, abiotic degradation, bioconcentration, etc.

StringWithMarkup.String: Methylmercury ion can be produced in bottom sediments, rotten fish and soil from inorganic mercury by biological activity. Methylmercury ion is also formed in the environment from bacterial action on the metal which enters the environment via spills and effluent. Potential sources of mercury which may result in methylmercury formation are from release of inorganic mercury to the environment from disposal of municipal wastes in sanitary landfills and subsequent leaching from these sites, emissions from refuse incineration, non-ferrous metal production, iron and steel production, fossil fuel combustion, chlor-alkali industries, and atmospheric fallout. Its former production and use as a fungicide treatment for grains resulted in its direct release to the environment. Methylmercury ion arises largely, if not solely, from the methylation of inorganic mercury. Major non-commercial sources of which are degassing of the earth's crust, emissions from volcanoes, and evaporation from natural bodies of water. If released to the atmosphere, wet and dry deposition would probably be important fate processes. Methylmercury is part of the biogeochemical cycle of mercury. Where mercury is found in soil, methylmercury may also be found since it is both produced and destroyed by microbial processes involving mercury compounds. Volatilization from moist soil surfaces is not expected because methylmercury exists as a cation and cations do not volatilize. In water, methylmercury is both produced and destroyed by microbial activity. Volatilization from water surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process based upon its cationic state. Methylmercury ion is soluble at low concentrations. Methylmercury is rapidly taken up by fish and other organisms either directly through water or through the food chain, and accumulated in their tissues where it is retained for relatively long periods of time (depuration half-life 1-3 years). Rates of methylmercury production and bioaccumulation depend not only on the abundance of inorganic mercury but also on a complex assortment of environmental variables which affect the activities and species composition of the microflora and the availability of the inorganic mercury for methylation. Methylmercury ion can react with free S-H groups of biologically important molecules, leading to diseases that have been caused by mercury and its derivatives. Consumption of fish and shellfish is the main source of methylmercury exposure in the general population. (SRC)

Section.Description: Pollutants are emitted from a range of natural and man-made (artificial) sources.  This section provides information on the natural sources of the compound as a pollutant.

Reference: Friberg, L., Nordberg, G.F., Kessler, E. and Vouk, V.B. (eds). Handbook of the Toxicology of Metals. 2nd ed. Vols I, II.: Amsterdam: Elsevier Science Publishers B.V., 1986., p. 393

StringWithMarkup.String: Methylmercury is formed naturally in aquatic and terrestrial environments from elemental mercury and mercuric mercury.

Reference: Doull, J., C.D. Klaassen, and M. D. Amdur (eds.). Casarett and Doull's Toxicology. 2nd ed. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co., 1980., p. 649

StringWithMarkup.String: Conditions for methylation by sediment microorganisms are strict and occur only within narrow pH range. Rate of synthesis of methylmercury also depends on redox potential, composition of microbial population, avail of Hg2+ and temp. Vitamin B12 derivatives are believed to be methylating agents ...

Reference: Klaassen, C.D., M.O. Amdur, Doull J. (eds.). Casarett and Doull's Toxicology. The Basic Science of Poisons. 5th ed. New York, NY: McGraw-Hill, 1995., p. 886

StringWithMarkup.String: Mercury is methylated through microbial reactions in the sediment. Methylmercury is much more bioavailable and toxic than inorganic mercury.

Reference: (1) Jenson S, Jernelov A; Nature 223: 753-4 (1969)
(2) Surma-Aho K et al; Chemosphere 14: 353-72 (1986)
(3) Kelly CA et al; Environ Sci Technol 31: 1334-44 (1997)
(4) WHO; Environmental Health Criteria 101. Methylmercury. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health Organization. International Programme on Chemical Safety (1990)
(5) Braga MCB et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 164: 69-92 (2000)
(6) Malm O et al; Sci Total Environ 175: 127-40 (1995)
(7) Compeau G, Bartha R; Appl Environ Microbiol 48: 1203-7 (1984)

StringWithMarkup.String: Environmental methylmercury arises largely, if not solely, from the methylation of inorganic mercury, major non-commercial sources of which are degassing of the earth's crust, emissions from volcanoes, and evaporation from natural bodies of water(4). Methylmercury can be produced in bottom sediments, rotten fish and soil from inorganic mercury by biological activity(1,2). Experimental flooding of a 16 ha boreal forest wetland located in the Experimental Lakes Area, northwest Ontario, Canada resulted in increased levels of methylmercury ion in the water (exceeding 2 ng/L), brought about by an increase in microbial methylation of inorganic mercury activity(3). Prior to flooding, avg methylmercury concn was 0.1 ng/L; after flooding - 0.9 ng/L(3). During the winter and following the fall drawdown, the pond became completely anoxic and methylmercury levels were at 2.8 ng/L(3). The avg % of total mercury that was methylmercury increased from 4% to 32% after flooding(3). Concn of methylmercury in sediments, water and fish is probably influenced by several factors such as mercury concn, microbial activity, organic matter, presence of methyl group donors, pH, Eh, and O2(5,6). Sulfate, manganese, and iron concns influence methylation/demethylation as well(5). Mercuric ion is the most suitable form for methylation; therefore, mercury methylation may be limited by the rate of Hg(0) oxidation(6). Using estuarine sediments from Cheesaquake State Park, NJ (pH = 6.8), methylation of mercury to monomethylmercury was enhanced under anaerobic, low salinity conditions; aerobic, high-salinity environments were less conducive to monomethylmercury synthesis(7).

Section.Description: Pollutants are emitted from a range of natural and man-made (artificial) sources.  This section provides information on the artificial sources of the compound as a pollutant.

Reference: (1) Cyr F et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 38: 775-82 (1987)
(2) Hutton M, Symon C; Sci Total Environ 57: 129-50 (1986)
(3) WHO; Environmental Health Criteria 101. Methylmercury. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health Organization. International Programme on Chemical Safety (1990)
(4) Braga MCB et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 164: 69-92 (2000)

(5) USEPA; Technology Transfer Network. Unified Air Toxics Website. Mercury and Compounds. Washington, DC: USEPA. Off Air Qual Plan Standards. Available from: https://www.epa.gov/ttn/atw/hlthef/mercury.html as of April, 2000.

StringWithMarkup.String: It is difficult to assess quantitatively the relative contributions of natural and anthropogenic mercury to run-off from land to natural bodies of water(3). Potential sources of methylmercury are from release of inorganic mercury to the environment from: disposal of municipal wastes in sanitary landfills and subsequent leaching from these sites(1,2), emissions from refuse incineration, non-ferrous metal production, iron and steel production, fossil fuel combustion, chlor-alkali industries, and atmospheric fallout(2). Methylmercury ion is also formed in the environment from bacterial action on the metal which enters the aquatic environment via activities resulting from gold mining(4). Methylmercury's former production and use as a fungicide-treatment for grains resulted in its direct release to the environment(5).

Section.Description: Environmental fate describes where this chemical goes when it gets out into the environment and how it might be chemically transformed in that process.  This section may provide information on multiple types of environmental fates of the chemical (e.g., aquatic fate, terrestrial fate, and atmospheric fate).

Reference: Compeau G, Bartha R; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 31 (4): 486 (1983)

StringWithMarkup.String: Environmental factors influence net amt of methylmercury in an ecosystem by shifting equilibrium of the opposing methylation and demethylation processes. Methylation is result of mercuric ion (Hg++) interference with biochemical C-1 transfer reactions. Demethylation is brought about by nonspecific hydrolytic and reductive enzyme processes. Studies have demonstrated a strong negative correlation between salinity of anaerobic sediments and their ability to form methylmercury from Hg++.

Reference: (1) Braga MCB et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 164: 69-92 (2000)
(2) Callahan MA et al; Water-Related Environmental Fate of 129 Priority Pollutants Vol. 1 pp. 14-1 to 14-11 USEPA-44/4-79-029a (1979)
(3) Ramamoorthy S et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 29: 167-73 (1982)
(4) Bisogni JJ; The Biogeochemistry of Mercury in the Environment. Nriagu JO, ed, NY, NY: Elsevier p. 214 (1979)

StringWithMarkup.String: TERRESTRIAL FATE: Volatilization of methylmercury ion from moist soil surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process given it is in the cation state and cations do not volatilize(SRC). Methylmercury ion is part of the biogeochemical cycle of mercury(1). Where mercury is found in soil, methylmercury ion may also be found since it is both produced and destroyed by microbial processes involving mercury compounds. Since mercury is cannot be destroyed under environmental conditions it remains available for transformation into methylmercury ion(2-4).

Reference: (1) Jackson TA; Can J Fish Aquat Sci 43: 1873-86 (1986)
(2) Ramamoorthy S et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 29: 167-73 (1982)

StringWithMarkup.String: AQUATIC FATE: Inorganic mercury introduced as a pollutant into natural waters is scavanged by particulate matter and deposited into bottom sediments. Free Hg++ is gradually released from this pool of slightly soluble inorganic mercury and is then transformed by microbial activity into methylmercury ion. Methylmercury ion diffuses into the water column and is taken up by fish and other organisms (either directly through water or through the food chain), and accumulated in their tissue. Rates of methylmercury ion production and bioaccumulation depend not only on the abundance of inorganic mercury but also on a complex assortment of environmental variables which affect the activities and species composition of the microflora and the availability of inorganic mercury for methylation. Stimulation of microbial growth by nutrients such as readily metabolized organic matter tends to promote methylation of the available (free bivalent) fraction of the inorganic mercury, although this tendency is counteracted to a greater or lesser extent by other microbial processes such as microbial breakdown (demethylation) of methylmercury ion and the formation of sulfides. The effects of environmental variables are complex and mercury transformation processes are highly dependent upon the characteristics of the system(1). Methylmercury ion, added to a river water system containing sediment, was sorbed onto the sediments reaching a maximum in 7 days. At first no conversion of methylmercury ion occurred, but after 7 days 35% inorganic mercury was produced and in 28 days 55% was produced(2).

Reference: (1) Sellers P et al; Nature 380: 694-7 (1996)
(2) Braga MCB et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 164: 69-92 (2000)

StringWithMarkup.String: AQUATIC FATE: Volatilization of methylmercury ion from water surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process given it is in the cation state and cations do not volatilize(SRC). Methylmercury ion is susceptible to abiotic photodegradation in epilimnetic lake water(1). Bioaccumulation occurs because mercury, when methylated, enters the food chain by rapid diffusion and tight binding to proteins in aquatic biota(2). The older an organism is, and the higher its position in the food chain, the greater the fraction of total mercury existing as methylmercury(2).

Reference: (1) Izrael YA, Tsyban AV; Environ Monit Assess 7: 5-23 (1986)
(2) Brzezinska-Paudyn A et al; Water, Air, and Soil Pollut 27: 45-56 (1986)

StringWithMarkup.String: ATMOSPHERIC FATE: If released to the atmosphere, wet and dry deposition would probably be important environmental fate processes(1,2).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

Reference: Callahan, M.A., M.W. Slimak, N.W. Gabel, et al. Water-Related Environmental Fate of 129 Priority Pollutants. Volume I. EPA-440/4 79-029a. Washington, DC: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, December 1979., p. 14-9

StringWithMarkup.String: Upon entering an aqueous system, virtually any mercurial cmpd may be microbially converted to methylmercury. /Mercurial cmpd/

Reference: (1) Ramamoorthy S et al; Bull Environ Contam Tox 29: 167-73 (1982)
(2) Callister SM, Winfrey MR; Water Air Soil Pollut 29: 453-65 (1986)
(3) Bisogni JJ; pp. 221-230 in The Biogeochemistry of Mercury in the Environment. Nriagu JO, ed. NY, NY: Elsevier (1974)

StringWithMarkup.String: Growing bacterial cells can transform methylmercury to the volatile elemental mercury form which is readily lost from the aquatic environment. However, living but non-growing bacterial and algal cells cause the demethylation of methylmercury to inorganic mercury, and dead bacterial cells can lead to the methylation of inorganic mercury to methylmercury(1). Temperature, organic enrichment, and oxygen level also influence methylation activity. Low temperature has been found to limit methylation in sediment, although methylmercury production has been observed in river sediments at 4 °C. Methylation activity is stimulated by the addition of organics and directly correlates with the organic content of the environment. Reports of the effects of oxygen level on mercury methylation are conflicting although most investigators have observed higher methylation rates in anaerobic sediments than in aerobic sediments(2,3). Mercury freshly added and bound to river sediment was found to be available for methylation by microorganisms. Thus, adsorption of inorganic mercury compounds may not render it biologically inactive(2). The following methylation rates were observed: anaerobic sediments with 0.1-50 mg/L Hg added, 0-1.9 ug Hg/day-volatile suspended solids; anaerobic sediments with 10-100 ug/g added, 1.9-9.7 ug Hg/day-volatile suspended solids; aerobic sediments with 10-100 ug/g added, 0-5.2 ug Hg/day-volatile suspended solids(3).

Reference: (1) Ramamoorthy S et al; Bull Environ Conatm Toxicol 29: 167-73 (1982)
(2) Ramlal PS et al; Appl Environ Microbiol 51: 110-4 (1986)

StringWithMarkup.String: Suspensions of microorganisms sorbed 81-82% of added methylmercury in the first 12 hours of incubation, with rates of conversion to inorganic mercury ranging between 50.6% in 7 days to 90% in 3 days(1). Ratio of biological methylation of mercury to biological demethylation of mercury by sediments, 0.02-0.83(2).

Section.Description: Abiotic degradation is a process by which a chemical substance is broken down into smaller molecules by non-biotic means (e.g., hydrolysis, photolysis, and oxidation).

Reference: (1) Braga MCB et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 164: 69-92 (2000)
(2) Callahan MA et al; Water-Related Environmental Fate of 129 Priority Pollutants Vol. 1 pp. 14-1 to 14-11 USEPA-44/4-79-029a (1979)
(3) Ramamoorthy S et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 29: 167-73 (1982)
(4) Bisogni JJ; The Biogeochemistry of Mercury in the Environment. Nriagu JO, ed, NY, NY: Elsevier p. 214 (1979)
(5) Sellers P et al; Nature 380: 694-7 (1996)

StringWithMarkup.String: Methylmercury is part of the biogeochemical cycle of mercury(1). It is kinetically inert and not amenable to decomposition so once formed, methylmercury ion is not readily demethylated(1). The neutral methylmercury ion species are soluble at the low concentrations at which they are formed, and thus escape into the water by diffusion and is dispersed by turbulence and convective circulation(1). Methylmercury may be transformed into other organic and inorganic mercury compounds by microbial processes and possibly some chemical processes(2-4). Net methylmercury production depends on the balance between methylation and demethylation which is influenced in a complex and variable manner of biological and physicochemical processes such as pH, temperature, dissolved organic carbon, oxygen concentration, mercury and methylmercury concentration and availability(1). Sulfate, manganese, and iron concentrations influence methylation/demethylation as well(1). Methlmercury was shown to be susceptible to abiotic photodegradation in epilimnetic lake water samples from the Experimental Lakes Area in northwestern Ontario, Canada(5). The rates were first order with respect to methylmercury concentrations and intensity of solar radiation; a photodegration rate constant of 0.43/day was estimated(5), corresponding to a half-life of 1.6 days(SRC).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

Reference: USEPA/OWRS; Quality Criteria for Water 1986 (1986) EPA 440/5-86-001

StringWithMarkup.String: Bioconcentration factors of 10,000 and 40,000 have been obtained for mercuric chloride and methylmercury with oyster.

Reference: (1) Simon M et al; Ullmann's Encycl Indust Chem. 5th ed. Weinheim, Germany: VCH A16: 290 (1990)
(2) WHO; Environmental Health Criteria 101. Methylmercury. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health Organization. International Programme on Chemical Safety (1990)
(3) Jenson S, Jernelov A; Nature 223: 753-4 (1969)
(4) Biddinger GR, Gloss SP; Res Rev 91: 103-46 (1984)
(5) Callahan MA et al; Water-Related Environmental Fate of 129 Priority Pollutants Vol. 1 pp. 14-1 to 14-11 USEPA-44/4-79-029a (1979)
(6) Ribeyre F et al; Ecotox Environ Saf 32: 1-11 (1995)
(7) Ribeyre F, Boudou A; Water Air Soil Pollut 23: 169-86 (1984)

StringWithMarkup.String: Methylmercury can react with free S-H groups of biologically important molecules(1). The change of speciation of mercury from inorganic to methylated is the first step in aquatic bioaccumulation(2). Fish readily bioconcentrate methylmercury either directly through water or through components of the food chain(3). Using an aquatic model of methylmercury uptake by Ottawa River (Canada) yellow perch (Perca flavescens) and combining results from field experiments, it was shown that 80% of the methylmercury present in food and 12% present in the water passing over the gills was accumulated by the fish(4). Another study determined that rainbow trout accumulated 10% of methylmercury via the gills and 70% via ingestion(4). Factors which affect the observed levels of mercury in plants and animals at different trophic levels include age, surface area, metabolism, habitat, and activity(5). Loss appears to occur in two stages: first, methylmercury is distributed throughout the tissues, over a period of a few weeks, and then is discharged very slowly from the established binding sites(5). The depurative half-life in fish varies between 1 and 3 years(5). In a 12-day bioaccumulation study using zebrafish (Brachydanio rerio), it was noted that when silver is present in the water jointly with methylmercury, it exerts a negative action on mercury bioaccumulation in the fish, at the whole organism level(6). Following direct contamination of Salmo gairdneri using HgCl2 and CH3HgCl for 30 days, it was noted that mercury accumulation was 6 times greater when methylmercury was used(7).

Reference: (1) Gagnon C, Fisher NS; Environ Sci Technol 31: 993-8 (1997)
(2) Rouleau C et al; Appl Organometal Chem 9: 327-34 (1995)
(3) Odin M et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 31: 339-49 (1996)

StringWithMarkup.String: The bioavailability of sediment-bound Hg(II) and CH3Hg(II) for benthic organisms must be evaluated with regard to key geochemical factors such as organic matter, iron and manganese oxides that vary considerably among coastal sediments(1). Using the common mussel, Mytilus edulis, from the shore at Flax Pond, Long Island, NY, assimilation efficiencies from suspended particles ranged from 55% in natural sediment to 5% in clay(1). Starfish, Leptasterias polaris, exposed for 48 hrs to seawater containing 0.35 nmol/cu dm of radiolabeled methylmercury accumulated 0.53 nmol, corresponding to a first-order uptake rate constant of 0.102/hr(2). Introduction of 0.2 and 1.0 ug/L methylmercury into a sediment/water aquarium with burrowing mayfly nymphs of Hexagenia rigida and a 15 day exposure resulted in a mercury concentration in the nymphs of 400 and 1150 ug/L at 15 °C and 400 and 750 ug/L at 25 °C, respectively(3). The effect of pH appears to be minimal at the lower concentration but substantial using the high concentration, e.g. 800 and 2000 ug/L at pH 5 and pH 7.5, respectively, temperature of 25 °C(3).

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) Hintelmann H et al; Environ Sci Toxicol 31: 489-95 (1997)
(2) Yin Y et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 16: 2457-62 (1997)
(3) Desauziers V et al; Environ Toxicol 18: 1009-18 (1997)
(4) Miskimmin BM; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 47: 743-50 (1991)

StringWithMarkup.String: Methylmercury(II) contents in humic and fulvic acids from lakes in Ontario Canada were measured and it was found that losses of methylmercury(II) from solutions containing 0.5-100 ng/L MeHg(II) and 10 mg/L humic substances are negligible over 24 hrs, suggesting that humic materials have a high binding capacity for methylmercury(II) and a great accumulation potential(1). Using a 2X10-2 M concentration, four soils, Freehold sandy loam - A horizon, Freehold sandy loam - B horizon, Penn silt loam, and Rockaway stony loam collected from New Jersey - were used in assessing the effects of pH, chloride, and calcium on monomethylmercury adsorption(2). Maximum adsorption occurred at near pH 6 for all four soils and a larger silt plus clay content and a larger organic matter content resulted in greater adsorption(2). Methylmercury molecules are rapidly adsorbed on clay minerals through several mechanisms, which depend on the structure of the clays; from highest affinity to least are as follows: expandable clays (montmorillonite), Kf = 0.233, is greater than nonexpandable clays (kaolinite), Kf = 0.180, and with mineral oxides, goethite being greater than hausmanite(3). The watershed may be influential in introducing methylmercury to fast-flushing, high-DOC lakes, and once in the water column, dissolved organic carbon-bound methylmercury may be resistant to entering lake sediments(4).

Reference: (1) Amirbahman A et al; Environ Sci Technol 36: 690-695 (2002)

StringWithMarkup.String: Methylmercury equilibrium binding constants to three different humic acids indicate that the extent of sorption does not show a strong dependence with pH 5 to pH 9(1). Mercury atom is highly polarized; methylmercury therefore forms strong covalent bonds with bases such as reduced sulfur. Reduced sulfur present in dissolved organic matter in sediments therefore creates important binding sites.

Section.Description: Volatilization of chemicals from water/soil is the transfer of the chemical as a gas through the water-air or soil-air interface under environmental conditions

Reference: Nat'l Research Council Canada; Effects of Mercury in the Canadian Environment p.81 (1979) NRCC No. 16739

StringWithMarkup.String: ... In those systems where the residence time of the water is low (rivers and streams), mercury (Hg) is in most cases removed quite quickly, perhaps by as much as 50% per yr: ie the half-life of the Hg would be of the order of 1 yr or more. The mechanisms largely responsible must be (i) ingestion or absorption and subsequent removal by biological materials and organisms, and (ii) transformation to a more volatile chemical form which can escape from the sediment and from the entire aquatic system.

Reference: (1) Carpi A et al; J Environ Qual 26: 1650-55 (1997)
(2) Miskimmin BM; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 47: 743-50 (1991)

StringWithMarkup.String: Volatilization of methylmercury ion from water and moist soil surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process given it is in the cation state and cations do not volatilize(SRC). However, it has been shown that methylmercury was transported from a sludge-amended soil contaminated with inorganic and methylmercury to the environment by emission to the atmosphere(1). Using sediments from East Bay Lake in northwestern Ontario, Canada, experiments were performed to examine the effect of dissolved organic carbon on the partitioning of methylmercury between lake sediments and water(2). Approximately 80% of the methylmercury added in the partitioning experiment was lost either due to demethylation or volatilization(2). This occurred more slowly with increasing dissolved organic carbon concentration(2).

Section.Description: Concentrations of this chemical in water in various stages of hydrologic cycle (e.g., drinking water, ground water, surface water, and rain/snow).

Reference: 1) Brzezinska-Paudyn A et al; Water Air Soil Pollut 27: 45-56 (1986) (2) Campbell KR et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 17: 1191-8 (1998) (3) Kim JP, Burggraaf S; Water Air Soil Pollut 115: 535-46 (1999)

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Methylmercury content in the Humber River (Canada) was 10 ng/L; in unpolluted inland waters in Canada, 1-3 ng/L(1). Surface water samples were collected from Poplar Creek, Oak Ridge, TN, where, as a result of the lithium-isotope separation process used in the production of thermonuclear fusion weapons during the mid-1950s and early 1960s, 150 tons of mercury were released(2). These samples contained 0.08-0.7 ng/L and 0.05-0.3 ng/L methylmercury downstream and upstream from the East Fork Poplar Creek confluence, respectively(2). Concentrations increased with distance downstream from the source. High concentrations of methylmercury in surface water and sediment near the mouth of Poplar Creek appear to be the result of sediment deposition and resuspension, apparently caused by the stronger Clinch River current acting as a barrier and its backflow into the creek as a result of hydropower operations(2). Methylmercury concentrations in Okareka, Okaro, Tarawera, Rotorua, and Rotomahana Lakes, New Zealand were 0.09, 0.51, 0.21, 0.23, and 0.36 ng/L from samples taken summer and fall of 1993 and 1994(3).

Reference: (1) Hines NA et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 6610-6617 (2004)
(2) Gray JE et al; Sci Total Environ 260: 21-33 (2000)

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Levels of methylmercury in porewater or bottom water from Spring Lake in the Marcell Experimental Forest of northern Minnesota were measured as (ng/L; depth cm): 0.62(1-5); 0.69 (6-10); 0.56 (11-15); 0.45 (16-20); 0.33 (21-30); 0.31 (31-50); not available (41-50), collected on April 6, 2000(1). Mercury concentrations were typically less than 1800 ng/L in surface waters collected from streams in a region of abandoned mercury mines in the Kuskokwim River Basin, southwestern Alaska, but may contain as much as 2500 ng/L(2). Methylmercury concentrations were less than 1.5 ng/L, corresponding to less than 3% of total mercury(2).

Reference: (1) Roy V et al; Environ Sci Technol 43 (15): 5605-11 (2009).

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Beaver impoundments flood forested areas and may be important production sites for methylmercury (MeHg) because of the resulting enhanced microbial activity and oxygen depletion. The influence of 17 beaver impoundments on streamwater chemistry (total mercury (THg), MeHg, nutrients, cations, and anions) was investigated by sampling sites located along vegetation and pond-age gradients in the Laurentian region, southwestern Quebec (Canada), sampled from August 17 to September 1, 2006. Recently inundated beaver ponds (< 10 years old) and those located in coniferous watersheds had the highest MeHg concentrations (range, 0.10-4.53 ng/L) and greatest methylation efficiencies (% THg as MeHg; range, 10-74%)(1).

Reference: (1) Brzezinska-Paudyn A et al; Water Air Soil Pollut 27: 45-56 (1986)

StringWithMarkup.String: RAIN/SNOW/FOG: Methylmercury content in dissolved form in snow collected in Canada: Toronto, 34 ng/L; Etobicoke, 48 ng/L; Oakville, 34 ng/L; North York, 20 ng/L; and Kingston (countryside), 12 ng/L(1).

Section.Description: Concentration of this compound in effluent.  Effluent is wastewater (treated or untreated) discharged into surface waters from a treatment plant, sewer, or industrial outfall.

Reference: (1) Porvari P et al; Environ Sci Technol 37: 389-2393 (2003)

StringWithMarkup.String: Median methylmercury concentration was reported as 0.35 ng/L, with output loads of 0.011-0.36 h/sq km-annum over 3 years in a small spruce forest catchment following autumn 1997 clear cutting, 1998 soil mounding, and 1999 replanting of a Norway Spruce stand in Sweden; this suggests that clear cutting and/or soil treatment greatly increases the mobility of methylmercury accumulated in forest soils(1).

Reference: (1) Hintelmann H et al; Environ Sci Technol 29: 1845-50 (1995)

StringWithMarkup.String: There are still a number of questions concerning the exact pathways of production, release, and accumulation of methylmercury ion in the aquatic food web(1). No direct evidence has been found for a direct discharge of methylmercury species from point sources into the environment with the exception of the first observation of poisoning by methylmercury compounds at Minamata, Niigata, Japan(1).

Section.Description: Concentrations of this compound in sediment/soil.

Reference: (1) DiGiulio RT, Ryan EA; Water Air Soil Pollut 33: 205-19 (1987)
(2) Tremblay A et al; Sci Total Environ 219: 209-21 (1998)
(3) Hintelmann H et al; Environ Sci Technol 29: 1845-50 (1995)

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: 1983-84, peat soil from coastal region of North Carolina, total mercury content 40-193 ng/g dry wt, methylmercury not detected, detection limit 25 ng/g dry wt(1). The concentration in flooded soils from the Laforge hydroelectric reservoir in northern Quebec, Canada ranged from 0.4-1.5 ng/g d/w (forest soil) and 3-5 ng/g d/w (peat)(2); in the impoundment below the dam, concentrations were 0.6-2 ng/g d/w (forest soil) m and 0.3-0.7 ng/g d/w (peat)(2). Soil samples from a chlor alkali plant and acetaldehyde processing facility near a mining area at Idrija, Slovenia contained methylmercury ion concentrations ranging from <3 to 200 ug Hg/kg(3). In soils from chlor alkali and acetaldehyde plants at Schkopau, East Germany, methylmercury ion concentrations ranged from 6-196 ug Hg/kg, and not detected-43 ug Hg/kg, respectively(3). Soil samples from a fungicide production plant in Marktredwitz, Bavaria, Germany contained elevated levels methylmercury, concentration not specified, compared to the natural background level suggested in the literature of <1 ug Hg/kg(3). Methylmercury was detected, not quantified in soil from the site of a demolished phenylmercury chloride warehouse in Weissenfels, East Germany(3).

Reference: (1) DiGiulio RT, Ryan EA; Water Air Soil Pollut 33: 205-19 (1987)
(2) Surma-Aho K et al; Chemosphere 15: 353-72 (1986)
(3) Tremblay A et al; Sci Total Environ 219: 209-21 (1998)

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Sediment from canals and the Pungo River, NC receiving drainage from peatlands, total mercury content 8-20 ng/g dry wt, methylmercury not detected, detection limit 25 ng/g dry wt(1). Methylmercury ion concentrations varied from about 2 to 28 ng Hg/g dry weight in sediments collected from the Carson River system in Nevada which is contaminated as a result of mercury mining(5). Sediment samples were collected from Poplar Creek, Oak Ridge, TN, where, as a result of the lithium-isotope separation process used in the production of thermonuclear fusion weapons during the mid-1950s and early 1960s, 150 tons of mercury were released(6). These samples contained 1.0-12 ng/g methylmercury downstream from the East Fork Poplar Creek confluence, and increased with distance downstream from the source(6). High concentrations of methylmercury in surface water and sediment near the mouth of Poplar Creek appear to be the result of sediment deposition and resuspension, apparently caused by the stronger Clinch River current acting as a barrier and its backflow into the creek as a result of hydropower operations(6). 1980-1984, sediments from Finnish lakes and reservoirs, 5 sites (organic mercury content), mean concentration range 0.09-0.21 mg/kg dry wt(2). The concentration in sediment from Lake 136 near the Laforge hydroelectric reservoir in northern Quebec, Canada ranged from 0.4-1.6 ng/g dry wt(3). Concentrations of methylmercury in the sedimenting section and sediment from stratified Finnish forest lakes ranged from 57.4-196 ng/g dry wt, and 134-254 ng/g dry wt, respectively(4). A median concentration of 4.0 ng/g dry wt was measured in suspended particulate matter collected from the Arctic region between June and October 1991(7). Sediments in the Kosseine River, Germany near a fungicide producing plant contained methylmercury ion concentrations of 180, 35, and 49 mg Hg/kg at 1, 3, and 4 km distance downstream from the discharge point(8).

Reference: (1) Hines NA et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 6610-6617 (2004)
(2) Gray JE et al; Sci Total Environ 260: 21-33 (2000)

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Levels of methylmercury in sediment cores from Spring Lake in the Marcell Experimental Forest of northern Minnesota were measured as (ng/g dry wt; depth cm): 1.6 (1-5); 0.85 (6-10); 0.51 (11-15); 0.30 (16-20); 0.22 (21-30); 0.10 (31-50); 0.059 (41-50), collected on April 6, 2000(1). Mercury concentrations were typically greater than 1000 ug/g total mercury in sediments collected downstream from an abandoned mercury mine in the Kuskokwim River Basin, southwestern Alaska(2). A concentration of 5,500 ug/g total mercury was reported at the Red Devil Mine. Methylmercury concentrations in stream-sediment samples collected from Red Devil Creek and Cinnabar Creek were generally below 5.0 ng/g and those from the Red Top Mine were below 1.0 ng/g(2). Sediments from a flooded beaver pond 2 km downstream from the Cinnabar Creek mine contained 31 ng/g methylmercury(2).

Reference: (1) Chetelat J et al; Environ Sci Technol 42 (24): 9110-5 (2008).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Sediment studies were conducted on lakes and ponds located on 3 islands of the Canadian High Arctic, specifically Cornwallis, Devon, and Somerset, 74-76 deg N latitude in July and August of 2005 and 2006. Methylmercury mean concentration in near-shore sediments of 18 lakes and ponds was 0.13 ng/g dry weight (3.3 ng/g dry weight organic matter), ranging from <0.04 to 0.64 ng/g dry weight (0.9-17.7 ng/g dry weight organic matter). The mean concentration in profundal sediment from 7 lakes was 0.52 ng/g dry weight (3.6 ng/g dry weight organic matter), ranging from 0.13-1.09 ng/g dry weight (2.1-6.3 ng.g dry weight organic mater)(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: The mean methylmercury (as the chloride) concentration in broilers and hens from Greece was  (wet weight): breast (broilers) 0.9 ppb, leg (broilers) 0.7 ppb, liver (broilers) 2.6 ppb; breast (hens) 1.8 ppb, leg (hens) 1.4 ppb, liver (hens) 6.1 ppb(1). Methylmercury concentrations in Swedish foods in 1966 were as follows (mg of Hg/kg): ox meat, 0.068; poultry, 0.17; pig liver, 0.75-0.95; egg yolk, 0.005-0.009; egg white, 0.009-0.011; perch, 0.20-2.99; pike, 0.55-3.11; and cod, 0.022-0.055(2).

Reference: (1) Endo T et al; Chemosphere 54: 1653-1662 (2004)

StringWithMarkup.String: Methylmercury levels in boiled whale livers purchased between 1999 and 2001 from Japanese food retail outlets were as follows (ug/g wet gram): Risso's dolphin, 7.43-15.3; pilot whale, 9.83-14.8; striped/bottlenose/common dolphin, 3.01-23.5; minke whale, 0.12-20.3. Levels in boiled whale lungs were as follows (ug/g wet gram): Risso's dolphin, 0.20-2.43; pilot whale, 0.50-2.08; striped/bottlenose/common dolphin, 1.6-9.93; minke whale, 0.12-1.80. Levels in boiled whale kidneys were as follows (ug/g wet gram): Risso's dolphin, 1.59-2.76; striped/bottlenose/common dolphin, 0.62-21.0; minke whale, 0.01-1.54. Levels in whale red meat were as follows (ug/g wet gram): Risso's dolphin, 0.09-9.21; pilot whale, 5.38-13.8; striped/bottlenose/common dolphin, 2.17-63.4; Baird's beaked whale, 1.48-5.30. Levels in whale red meat from mysticetes were as follows (ug/g wet gram): minke whale, 0.04-0.12; Bryde's whale, 0.09(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: Plant samples, collected randomly in October 1992 and May 1993 from the Experimental Lakes Area near Kenora, Ontario, Canada, contained the following mean methylmercury concentrations: tree and shrub leaves and needles, 0.13 ug/kg; lichens 6.13 ug/kg; sedges/macrophytes 1.99 ug/kg; Sphagnum: hummucks 0.45 ug/kg; hollow/lawn, 1.02; pond/stream, 20.40; and feather mosses, 38.65 ug/kg(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: The ratio of organic mercury to total mercury is generally very high in fish and other aquatic organisms with organic mercury occurring almost entirely in the form of monomethylmercury(1-3). The natural or "background" mercury concentration for most freshwater fish species appear to range from 50-200 ug/kg and may be <10 ug/kg in short-lived herbivorous species(2). Mercury levels in the majority of commercially important species are <500 ug/kg with average levels usually 100-200 ug/kg except for the larger predatory species such as tuna and swordfish, and also for large slow-growing fish such as halibut(2). FDA fiscal year 1979 survey results (mean total mercury content in muscle tissue, ug/kg wet wt): bass, fresh water - 190; bass, salt water - 70; bluefish - 190; carp - 110; catfish - 100; cod - 150; halibut - 270; perch, fresh water - 130; perch, salt water - 170; pike, walleye - 260; pollack - 50; swordfish - 830; trout, fresh water - 130; trout, sea - 90; white fish - 60(3). Mean mercury levels in selected Great Lake fish as reported in an FDA 1970 survey (ug/kg wet wt) were as follows: Lake Erie: walleye - 580, perch - 240, white bass - 490, and smallmouth bass - 510; Lake St Clair: perch, 880, all other species - 480; Lake Michigan, all types - 110; Lake Ontario, all types - 300; Lake Huron, all types - 190; and Lake Superior, all types - 130(3). In a 1983-84 study, clams collected from the Pungo River in North Carolina contained a total mercury content of 25-32 ng/g wet wt; methylmercury was not detected, detection limit 25 ng/g wet wt(4).

Reference: (1) Hagel P; Environ Monit Assess 7: 257-62 (1986)
(2) Surma-Aho K et al; Chemosphere 15: 353-72 (1986)
(3) May K et al; Toxicol Environ Chem 13: 153-9 (1987)
(4) Riisgard HV et al; Marine Biology 86: 55-62 (1985)
(5) Pieters H, Geuke V; Wat Sci Tech 30: 213-9 (1994)

StringWithMarkup.String: Results from a 1985 survey by the Netherland Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries (total mercury content, mg/kg wet wt) are as follows: sole, 0.09; cod, 0.1; herring, 0.05; shrimp, 0.09; mussel, 0.05; pike-perch, 0.3; and eel, 0.3(1). Organic mercury content in samples collected from 1980 to 1984 from Finnish lakes and reservoirs (5 sites) were as follows: fish, mean concentration range 290-1, 690 ug/kg wet wt; zoobenthos, mean concentration range 40-186 ug/kg wet wt; and zooplankton, mean concentration range 180-380 ug/kg dry wt(2). Samples of yellow eel from various locations in the Dutch Rhine Delta were analyzed. It was noted that accumulation rates and levels of mercury were much higher in the western Rhine delta (1993, 0.25-0.45 mg Hg/kg), which has continuously served as a sedimentation basin for contaminated suspended matter transported from upstream regions, than in the eastern delta (1993, 0.15-0.29 mg Hg/kg), and that mercury concentration also tends to increase with age and length(5). Methylmercury concentrations in 4 fish species from the Rhine River delta in the Netherlands were as follows (mg/kg Hg w/w): pike-perch, 0.24-0.32; yellow eel, 0.080-0.49; roach, 0.050-0.097; and smelt >0.13-0.280, representing 100-120, 85-107, 92-100, and >85-128% methylmercury to total Hg, respectively(5). Levels in Anodonta, blue mussels, and zebra mussels from the same region were 0.006, 0.011, and 0.007-0.008 mg/kg Hg wet wt, representing 57, 47, and 30-70% methylmercury to total Hg, respectively(5). Methylmercury concentrations in samples from the Baltic Sea were as follows: fish, 12.5-40.3 ug/kg; mussels, 9.8-16.4 ug/kg; and algae, <0.003-1.4 ug/kg, with the percentage of total mercury attributable to methylmercury being 73.1-99% in fish, 20.1-55.6% in mussels, and <0.2-6.0% in algae(3). During 1981-82, mussels were collected in chronically mercury polluted waters in Finland and the methylmercury content was determined to be 59.8-468.2 ug/kg wet wt(4).

Reference: (1) Malm O et al; Sci Total Environ 175: 127-40 (1995)
(2) Akagi H et al; Sci Total Environ 175: 85-95 (1995)
(3) WHO; Environmental Health Criteria 202. Methylmercury. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health Organization. International Programme on Chemical Safety (1990)
(4) Schladot JD et al; Chemosphere 34: 2133-42 (1997)
(5) Falter R et al; Chemosphere 29: 1333-8 (1994)

StringWithMarkup.String: Carnivorous (piscivorous) fish from several different gold mining areas along the Amazon River in Brazil have effectively shown higher mercury concentrations than fish from lower trophic levels(1). It is assumed that nearly all mercury found in fish is in the form of methylmercury(1). Methylmercury levels in fish from the main gold mining area in the Tapajos river basin, Brazil, as well as from Tres Bocas facing the lake in Amapa state were up to 3.82 ppm, and most of the fish from upstream and some from downstream exceeded the allowable level of 0.5 ppm in Brazil(2). Levels greater than 1200 ug/kg have been found in the edible portions of shark, swordfish, and Mediterranean tuna. Similar levels have been found in pike, walleye, and bass taken from polluted fresh waters(3). Methylmercury content in muscles of the sedentary eel-pout from the North Sea (Jade Bay and Meldorf Bay) and the Baltic Sea (Darsser Ort) in 1994 and 1995 were 62 and 96 ug,g wet wt and 85 and 116 ug/g wet wt, and 35 and 38 ug/g wet wt, respectively(4). Samples of fish collected in June, 1993 near Neckargemuend on the Neckar River, contained the following methylmercury ion concentration ranges: 72-445, 96-290, 16-169, 60-432, and 812 ug/kg in eel, perch, roach, chub, and barbel, respectively, concentration being in proportion to fat content in the fish(5).

Reference: (1) Hammerschmidt CR et al; Environ Sci Technol 33: 999-1003 (1999)

StringWithMarkup.String: It was observed that there is a strong correlation with the concentration of mercury in fish eggs and that in the maternal carcass. Concentrations of mercury in eggs and carcasses were inversely correlated with lake water pH, acid-neutralizing capacity, calcium, and dissolved organic carbon(1). Eggs from yellow perch (Perca flavescens) from four seepage lakes in northern Wisconsin with a pH range of 6.1-7.0 ranged from 2-600 ng/g dry wt(1).
For more Fish/Seafood Concentrations (Complete) data for Methylmercury Cation (6 total), please visit the HSDB record page.

StringWithMarkup.String: From 1980-1984, fish-eating birds (goldeneye) collected at Finnish lakes and reservoirs, 4 sites (organic mercury content assumed to be almost entirely in the form of monomethylmercury), showed a mean concentration range of 0.10-0.38 mg/kg fresh weight(1). In 1980, total mercury content of Hawaiian seabird eggs sampled was 0.122-0.359 ug/g wet wt(2). In 1978, total mercury content of Royal Tern eggs from the central Texas coast had a mean concentration range of 1.11-1.27 ppm(3). Liver, muscle, and kidney samples from nine species of seabirds were analyzed for methylmercury, with mean percentages of 35, 36, and 66% of total mercury, respectively(4). Methylmercury concentrations in livers from cormorant and duck from the Rhine River delta in the Netherlands were 2.92 and 0.19-0.42 mg/kg Hg wet wt, representing 98 and 79-100% methylmercury to total Hg, respectively(5). Methylmercury levels in tissues of two Risso's Dolphins (Grampus priseus) and one Cuvier's Beaked Whale (Ziphius cavirostris) stranded in Italy on the South Adriatic Sea between June and September 1996 were measured(6); mg/kg wet wt in muscle: 15.68, 14.96, and 7.00; in the lung: 5.84, 7.41, and 3.61; in the liver: 14.70; 7.35, and 9.85; and in the kidney: 5.80, 5.32, and 4.51, respectively(6). Levels of methylmercury in the muscle, liver, and kidney from 7 stranded sperm whales in the southern North Sea during the winter of 1994/95 ranged from (ug/g dry wt) 2.5-3-7, 0.8-3.0, and 0.2-1.4, respectively(7). These are lower than values reported for other toothed whales, possible due to their open ocean niche and diet of deep-sea cephalopods(7).

Reference: (1) Tremblay A et al; Sci Total Environ 219: 209-221 (1998)
(2) Pieters H, Geuke V; Wat Sci Tech 30: 213-9 (1994)

StringWithMarkup.String: Insects may be an important source of methylmercury for predators that rely on them as a food source and consequently are an important vector in the transfer of methylmercury from flooded soils and sediments into the food chain(1). Littoral zone insects (emerging) from a dam impoundment, the Laforge hydroelectric reservoir, and a natural lake in northern Quebec, Canada were collected during the summer of 1994 and measured for methylmercury(1). Concentration ranges were as follows: not detected to 296 ng/g dry wt (flooded peat) and not detected to 300 ng/g dry wt (flooded forest soil), not detected to 279 ng/g dry wt (flooded forest soil and not detected to 800 ng/g dry wt (flooded peat), and not detected to 90 ng/g dry wt, respectively(1). Methylmercury concentrations in Daphnia from the Rhine River delta in the Netherlands ranged from 0.015-0.142 mg/kg Hg wet wt, representing 3-33% methylmercury to total Hg(2).

Reference: (1) Chetelat J et al; Environ Sci Technol 42 (24): 9110-5 (2008).

StringWithMarkup.String: Lake-dwelling Arctic char (Salvelinus alpinus) are monitored internationally as a sentinel species for effects of atmospheric mercury deposition on Arctic fresh waters. Studies were conducted on 3 islands of the Canadian High Arctic, specifically Cornwallis, Devon, and Somerset, 74-76 deg N latitude in July and August of 2005 and 2006; seventeen lakes and five ponds were sampled. Chironomid larvae, pupae, and adults are distinct mercury sources for these landlocked fish, and evidence from nitrogen stable isotopes and published feeding studies suggest differential consumption of these stages may affect methylmercury uptake by Arctic char. Methylmercury concentrations (ng/g dry weight) were 5-100, 25-280, and 60-280 for larvae, pupae, and adults, respectively. It is concluded that biological and food web processes have a greater impact on methylmercury transfer to fish than atmospheric mercury deposition in High Arctic lakes(1).

Section.Description: Concentrations of this compound in milk.

Reference: USEPA/OST; Water Quality Criterion for the Protection of Human Health: Methylmercury p.2-5 (2001). Available from, as of February 10, 2010: https://www.epa.gov/waterscience/criteria/humanhealth/

StringWithMarkup.String: Methylmercury is excreted in breast milk ... The ratio of mercury in breast milk to mercury in whole blood was approximately 1:20 in women exposed to methylmercury via contaminated grain in Iraq between 1971 and 1972 ... Evidence from the Iraqi poisoning incident also showed that lactation decreased blood mercury clearance halftimes from 75 days in males and nonlactating females to 42 days in lactating females; the faster clearance due to lactation was confirmed in mice ... In mice, of the total mercury in the breast milk, approximately 60% was estimated to be methylmercury. /It was/ found that 16% of mercury in human breast milk is methylmercury. Studies in animals indicate that the mercury content of breast milk is proportional to the mercury content of plasma.

Reference: WHO; Environmental Health Criteria 101. Methylmercury. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health Organization. International Programme on Chemical Safety (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: In humans, after high oral intake of methylmercury for 2 months, the following values were reported (percentage of total mercury in tissues as inorganic mercury): ... breast milk, 39% ... .

StringWithMarkup.String: Using sediments from East Bay Lake in northwestern Ontario, Canada, 2 experiments were performed to examine the effect of dissolved organic carbon on the partitioning of methylmercury between lake sediments and water(1). Methylmercury produced during the 24-hr incubation period at 22 °C was quantified as % HgCl2 per liter added to sediment-water mixture that was methylated, 0.030, 0.052, and 0.90% at DOC levels of 550, 2800, and 3460 uM, respectively(1). Biota play an important role in the transport of methylmercury(2). Routine application of municipal sewage sludge to crop land significantly increased the concentration methylmercury in surface soil from 0.3 to 8.3 ug/kg(3). Sludge amended soil emitted an average of 12 to 24 pg per cu meter hour of methylmercury ion; and may increase regional atmospheric concentration of methylmercury ion by approximately 5%(3).

Section.Description: Potential way(s) in which people may come into contact with a hazardous chemical.  Examples of common exposure routes are inhalation, ingestion, skin/eye contact.

StringWithMarkup.String: Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to methylmercury via ingestion of food, especially fish, and contaminated drinking water. (SRC)

Reference: Friberg, L., G.R. Nordberg, and V.B. Vouk. Handbook on the Toxicology of Metals. New York: Elsevier North Holland, 1979., p. 510

StringWithMarkup.String: EXPOSURE TO METHYL- AND ETHYLMERCURY HAS BEEN DESCRIBED IN CONNECTION WITH MFR AND USE OF THESE SALTS IN CHEMICAL INDUSTRIAL WORKERS AND IN PERSONNEL CARRYING OUT SEED TREATMENT. DUE TO RESTRICTIONS ON AGRICULTURAL APPLICATIONS OF ALKYLMERCURY COMPOUNDS, OCCUPATIONAL EXPOSURE IS LIKELY TO BE RARE AT PRESENT IN MOST INDUSTRIALIZED COUNTRIES.

Reference: WHO; Environ Health Criteria: Mercury p. 20 (1976)

StringWithMarkup.String: Accumulation of methylmercury in aquatic and terrestrial food chains represents a potential hazard to man by consumption of certain species of oceanic fish, of fish or shellfish from contaminated waters, and of game birds in areas where methylmercury fungicides are used.

Reference: (1) USEPA; Technology Transfer Network. Unified Air Toxics Website. Mercury and Compounds. Washington, DC: USEPA. Off Air Qual Plan Standards. Available from: https://www.epa.gov/ttn/atw/hlthef/mercury.html as of April, 2000.

StringWithMarkup.String: Sources of past exposure to methylmercury include fungicide-treated grains and meat from animals fed this treated grain(1). However, fungicides containing mercury are now banned in the US, and therefore, this source of exposure is now negligible(1).

Reference: (1) Klaassen CD et al, eds; Casarett and Doull's Toxicology. 5th ed. NY, NY: McGraw-Hill, pp. 709-714 (1995)
(2) Simon M et al; Ullmann's Encycl Indust Chem. 5th ed. Weinheim, Germany: VCH A16: 290 (1990)

(6) Malm O et al; Sci Total Environ 175: 127-40 (1995)

StringWithMarkup.String: Methylmercury may diffuse into the atmosphere and return to the earth's crust or to bodies of water as methylmercury in rainfall(1). Consumption of fish and shellfish is the main source of methylmercury exposure in the general population(3-6). Fish and shellfish generally contain two orders of magnitude more mercury than other food items(3). It can react with free S-H groups of biologically important molecules, leading to diseases that have been caused by mercury and its derivatives(2). In the gold mining regions of the Amazon Basin, the critical exposure population is inhabitants of riverside villages that routinely eat fish and not the gold miners, with better economic conditions and diversified food options(6).

Reference: (1) Bennett BG; IARC 71: 115-28 (1986)

StringWithMarkup.String: ATMOSPHERIC INTAKE: 0.14 ug/day total mercury (elemental and methylmercury) (assuming an avg ambient concentration 7 ng/cu m)(1). FOOD INTAKE: 16.3 ug/day total mercury (assuming avg mercury concentration in fish, 0.4 ug/g and an avg concentration in other foods, 0.004 ug/g(1)).

StringWithMarkup.String: Human hair is accepted as the best indicator for assessment of contamination in populations exposed to methylmercury(1). In 1992, abnormally high levels of mercury (mean range of 7.3-49.8 with an high of 132.6 ppm) were found in human hair from Jacareacanga and Brasilia Legal located near the main gold mining area in the Tapajos river basin, Brazil, as well as from Tres Bocas facing the lake in Amapa state, whereas the levels were much lower in Ponta de Pedras, a long way downstream(2). Hair from people in different Mediterranean areas: 9 controls (negligible to moderate fish consumption), methylmercury concentration range 0.01-0.55 ug/g, avg concentration 0.16 ug/g; 26 people, residents of a coastal areas, concentration range 0.39-36.0 ug/g, avg concentration 3.68 ug/g(3). Hair of a Papua New Guinean population, 114 samples, methymercury concentration range 3.2-50.5 ug/g, avg concentration 15.5 ug/g; a nearby control group who consumed a similar amount of fish, 51 samples, methylmercury concentration range 0.62-25.7 ug/g, avg concentration 6.4 ug/g; and a control group who consumed fish much less frequently, 45 samples, methylmercury concentration range 0.33-9.0 ug/g, avg concentration 2.4 ug/g(4). Peruvian population chronically exposed to methylmercury due to long-term, heavy consumption of fish (70% of dietary protein came from fish), mean methylmercury blood level - 82 ng/mL(5). Human placentae, Italy, 22 samples, mean total organic mercury content 0.076 ug/g dry wt(6). In fishermen from two south Atlantic coastal areas of Spain, mean methylmercury ion content in hair was 8.28 ug/g and 6.72 ug/g(7). The concentration of methylmercury ion in seafood consumed by the fisherman were: Scrobicularia plana, 1.20 ug/g; Tapes decussatus, 0.039 ug/g(7).

Reference: (1) WHO; Environmental Health Criteria 101. Methylmercury. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health Organization. International Programme on Chemical Safety (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: In humans, after high oral intake of methylmercury for 2 months, the following values were reported (percentage of total mercury in tissues as inorganic mercury): whole blood, 7%; plasma, 22%; breast milk, 39%; urine, 73%; liver 16-40%(1).

Reference: (1) Stern AH et al; Arch Environ Health 56: 4-10 (2001)
(2) Bjornberg KA et al; Environ Health Perspect 111: 637-641 (2003)
(3) Barbosa AC et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 40: 439-44 (2001)

StringWithMarkup.String: Methylmercury levels in 17 hair samples from pregnant women in New Jersey ranged from <0.2 to 9.1 ug/mercury/gm hair, from a study conducted between July 1995 and April 1997(1). Mercury levels in 143 blood samples from this same population ranged from <0.5 to 32.0 ug/g, with only 15% of samples having concentrations above the detection limit of 0.5 ug/L. Participants reported on average 83 fish meals/year(1). Methylmercury levels in pregnant Swedish women ranged from 0.07-1.5 mg/kg hair and 0.10 to 5.7 ug/L cord blood; reported fish consumption was 6.7 times/month(2). Methyl mercury in hair of the riverine population of the Negro River, Amazon Basin ranged from 0 to 56.79 ug/g, in samples taken March 1998 from 149 individuals(3).

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
